summary: noun / technical. The diameter of the stylus tip, expressed in mils (thousandths.
definition: **noun / technical.** The diameter of the stylus tip, expressed in mils (thousandths of an inch) or micrometers; critical for matching [groove](../g/groove-wear.md) type — 3-mil for 78s, 1-mil for mono LP, 0.7-mil for stereo micro-groove. Standardized during the 1950s transition from shellac to vinyl, when the introduction of stereo required narrower grooves to accommodate dual-channel modulation. Using incorrect tip size causes immediate damage: oversized styli (like 3-mil 78 needles on LPs) obliterate groove walls, while undersized tips ride too deep, contacting unpolished groove bottoms and producing distortion. Modern audiophile styli measure 0.2×0.7-mil (elliptical) to 0.1×0.3-mil (Shibata, micro-line), with smaller contact areas tracking finer detail but demanding precise alignment. The 0.7-mil standard emerged from RCA and Columbia's stereo specifications in 1958, balancing trackability with groove density that allowed 20+ minutes per side. Collectors playing 78s must maintain dedicated 3-mil styli to avoid destroying irreplaceable shellac pressings, while modern reissue buyers benefit from advanced profiles that extract information original 1960s equipment missed entirely.
etymology: Derived from sewing needle terminology, adapted to phonograph use in the acoustic era; "mil" measurement (1/1000 inch) became standard in American audio engineering by the 1940s.
